channel.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
channel.description: So, lots of news between the two countries, lets have a civil chat about whats happening.

item.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:12, topic:540899”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=659764.msg4412013#msg4412013 date=1394126993]—
Let Russia get Crimea. The peninsula was given by a mistake and the people there want to be Russian. So why stop them?
[/quote]

Because they signed a treaty saying they would not do exactly what they did?

Because they had referendum from down the barrel of a gun?

Because there are ethnic minorities living in Crimea (Tatars) who have been historically oppressed by the Russian’s?

Of course, nobody did stop them and now they have thousands of troops lined up ready to invade the rest of Eastern Ukraine if the ethnic Russian’s there are seen to be mistreated by Putin and his cronies. It is amazing how spineless the EU & NATO really are, I would not call for military engagement but at least deploying troops to a region where Russian forces are far and away beyond those necessary for a complete invasion seems like sensible action. More over it’s time to pull the finger out and impose some real sanctions which really hurt the Russians, regardless of whether they hurt our home economies too - if only to stop this opportunistic land grabbing which Putin has spelled out for the past 15 years he has no intention of cutting back on.[/quote]
Ukraine is not a NATO member, Ukraine cannot expect help from them.

Read full topic

Let Russia get Crimea. The peninsula was given by a mistake and the people there want to be Russian. So why stop them?

Because they signed a treaty saying they would not do exactly what they did?

Because they had referendum from down the barrel of a gun?

Because there are ethnic minorities living in Crimea (Tatars) who have been historically oppressed by the Russian’s?

Of course, nobody did stop them and now they have thousands of troops lined up ready to invade the rest of Eastern Ukraine if the ethnic Russian’s there are seen to be mistreated by Putin and his cronies. It is amazing how spineless the EU & NATO really are, I would not call for military engagement but at least deploying troops to a region where Russian forces are far and away beyond those necessary for a complete invasion seems like sensible action. More over it’s time to pull the finger out and impose some real sanctions which really hurt the Russians, regardless of whether they hurt our home economies too - if only to stop this opportunistic land grabbing which Putin has spelled out for the past 15 years he has no intention of cutting back on.

Putin wants dat der trading port, the leader of the ukraine was pro-russia and putin is afraid a pro-western one will be put in power. there are also alot of gas lines going into russia through the ukraine

He’s doing the same thing the US did, double standard is retarded

item.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

13 year old data referring to the population of a country… I’m sure it has plenty of room to have skewed by now.

Read full topic

item.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“thiefmn6092, post:7, topic:540899”][quote author=Pure_ link=topic=659764.msg4411814#msg4411814 date=1394026517]
They are attempting to make up for lost territory and using the excuse of the small fraction of pro-Russians to accomplish it
[/quote]

you don’t know very much about Ukraine if you think the Russian population is small[/quote]Their 2001 consensus yielded: 77.8% Ukrainian, 17.3% Russian (I doubt it fluctuated too much, the proportions are probably still similar - in fact the figures note that the Russian populate dropped from 1989 to 2001 so we could assume the trend continues). They are a relatively small percentile of the nation, so 17% of the population being Russian hardly justifies a Russian takeover of the state. That said, all Russians aren’t nationalists, and certainly not pro-Putin, the same could be said for the Ukrainians.

ps Never claimed to know very much about Ukraine.

Read full topic

item.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
item.dc:creator: @thiefmn6092 thiefmn6092
item.description:

Pure_:

They are attempting to make up for lost territory and using the excuse of the small fraction of pro-Russians to accomplish it

you don’t know very much about Ukraine if you think the Russian population is small

item.title: Lets discuss Russia vs Ukraine
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

We’re in the era following the atomic age (assuming you believe it is over), if war happens both sides will ultimately lose. I think Russia is just testing the commitment of the Western powers, as far as ‘protecting’ the Balkan nations goes, they want to know if they can invade them without expecting resistance. They have been threatened so far but no solid action has been taken which will only bolster their ego. I think the chances of a full-scale war happening is very unlikely (I certainly hope it is).

[quote=“Newty, post:3, topic:540899”]Putin is proving that Russia is still a power rival to the U.S as far as the sphere of power in Europe is concerned. He is basically saying fudge you to the entire western world right now which is either very brave… or very stupid. Only time will tell to be honest.[/quote]I think he didn’t have to prove anything, we all know the strength of mother Russia.

[quote=“gravenfire23, post:2, topic:540899”]I’ve been following this for a few days now, I find it interesting that a lot of the Ukrainians seem to welcome Russia’s invasion. Although as far as I can tell the only reason they want to take over the Ukraine is something to do with increasing there stance in the natural gas industry, which to me seems a bit 19th century. But then again I don’t know much about politics or anything to do with things like this.[/quote]They are attempting to make up for lost territory and using the excuse of the small fraction of pro-Russians to accomplish it. Assuming the media is portraying the public consensus accurately, only the majority of the East is siding with Russia which could be due to the historic ties of Ukraine and Russia (ie Ukrainian soldiers fighting side by side with the Soviets in WW2).

Read full topic
